# PART IV – CONCLUSIONS
At this point in time, it is not entirely clear how the legal rules or norms of conduct will develop within this policy space. It is not surprising that the United States is pushing to create a strong normative and legal framework prohibiting acts of economic cyber espionage, because they have the most to lose and the least to gain from these types of activities. The United States generates major amounts of intellectual property and its firms routinely rely on sensitive and proprietary information in their business practices. At the same time, there is no ability within the United States’ system to translate stolen economic intelligence into an actionable intelligence product, because the United States does not have the ability to convey this stolen information to its domestic companies. After all, if the NSA were to steal the design for a revolutionary hybrid automotive engine from an Asian or European auto manufacturer, who would they give it to: Ford? General Motors? Chrysler? They would be effectively picking winners and losers in the free market economy, something which the United States Government tries not to do. It is also not surprising that the United States would seek a more permissive regime when it comes to security related intelligence, because the United States is widely believed to have the most sophisticated offensive cyber arsenal on the planet.
However, this push to bifurcate the rules – with one set of rules for economically motivated cyber espionage and one set for security related cyber espionage – sets up an interesting problem. The difficulty is that this framework would require target states to understand the motivation behind a particular intrusion in order to accurately gage the legality of that act. It also presupposes that a clear line can be drawn between economic and security interests – which of course is not true. Suppose for example that State A dropped a logic bomb on the central server of the national bank in State B. What if the purpose of this act was to activate the nefarious code only in the event of a kinetic conflict between the two states to undermine the economy within the target state? But, what if the purpose of the logic bomb was solely to undermine consumer confidence in that bank and to push consumer and business investments elsewhere? The act, placing nefarious code on the server, is the exact same. It is only the motivation that differs. And, in cyberspace, it will be difficult if not impossible to accurately assess the motivation behind any particular act. Therefore, the notion of setting up a dual regime with permissive rules for security related espionage and restrictive rules for economic espionage rests on top of two fallacies. First, that a target can tell the difference between acts that are economic in nature versus those that are security related, and that there is an actual difference between the two. And second, that a target will be able to ascertain why a particular clandestine cyber act was undertaken. This bifurcation of espionage related activities is simply not a sustainable way to create realistic rules of the road for espionage in cyber space.

# CYBER ESPIONAGE AND INTERNATIONAL LAW
## BY AARON SHULL
## INTRODUCTION
The place of espionage under international law is an uneasy one. Many look to state practice, and conclude that acts of espionage must surely be legal because so many states spy on one another. Others say that sending spies in to the territory of another state breaches the norm of territorial and sovereign integrity, and therefore acts of espionage should rightly be considered illegal pursuant to the relevant legal rules. The difficulty in assessing legality is amplified when analyzing cyber intrusions, because they do not offend the principle of territorial integrity in the same way that sending an actual state agent to gather human intelligence (colloquially referred to as “HUMINT”) would. This paper is an attempt to address these legal ambiguities.
However, because there is no public multilateral treaty that addresses acts of cyber espionage, recourse must be made to the customary rules to determine the position of espionage under international law. At its most basic level, customary law is comprised of the rules that emerge as a matter of past practice amongst nation states, and which come to govern future relations between them. The Statute of the International Court of Justice defines customary law as “evidence of a general practice accepted as law.” This has been interpreted to mean that for a customary norm of conduct to crystallize into a binding rule – gaining formal status under international law – two constituent criteria must be met. First, there must be widespread and consistent state practice. Second, the activity in question, or the abstinence of states from engaging in a particular activity, must be done out of a sense of legal compulsion. This second element, called *opinio juris*, is used to differentiate state actions that are legally obliged from those undertaken for some other purpose (like self-interest or comity).
The starting point for the application of international rules is the often cited *Lotus* principle, which asserts that a sovereign state may undertake any action they wish, as long as that action is not explicitly prohibited. The relevant question then becomes: Is there an explicit prohibition on acts of cyber espionage? The research goal of this paper is to answer that question, and in answering this question the paper will make three arguments.
First, that despite the fact that states routinely spy on each other, there is no evidence to support the proposition that state actors view cyber espionage as something that is legal under customary

INT'L L. & POL'Y 321, 321 (1996); Glenn Sulmasy & John Yoo, *Counterintuitive: Intelligence Operations and International Law*, 28 MICH. J. INT'L L. 625 (2007); Jeffrey H. Smith, Symposium, *State Intelligence Gathering and International Law: Keynote Address*, 28 MICH. J. INT'L L. 543, 545 (2007); Roger D. Scott, *Territorially Intrusive Intelligence Collection and International Law*, 46 A.F.L. REV. 217 (1999); Christopher D. Baker, *Tolerance of International Espionage: A Functional Approach*, 19 AM. U. INT'L L. REV. 1091, 1092 (2004).

Garcia-Mora, *Treason, Sedition and Espionage as Political Offenses Under the Law of Extradition*, 26 U. PITT. L. REV. 65, 79-80 (1964); Ingrid Delupis, *Foreign Warships and Immunity for Espionage*, 78 AM. J. INT'L L. 53, 67 (1984).

international law. In this regard, while instances of cyber espionage may not offend the territorial integrity of the target state like human spying would, a sound legal conclusion can be drawn that certain intrusions will offend the principle of non-interference under international law. And, if cyber intrusions offend the principle of non-interference, they are correctly considered to be illegal pursuant to the relevant customary rules.
Second, the forces that influence the behavior of both state and non-state actors in relation to cyber espionage are much more complicated than a simple determination of legality. Cyber espionage may be illegal, but this vague notion of illegality pursuant to an even vaguer general rule of customary law acts as an extremely poor constraint on state behaviour. Poorly constrained, it is no surprise that states have engaged in a massive campaign of political, economic and military cyber espionage activities. However, many states view the current situation characterized by widespread (and largely unchecked) acts of cyber espionage as unsustainable. It is the explosion in the number of targets created by the Internet that has led the global community in to a process of what international relations scholars call ‘regime’ building, or what international lawyers call the ‘transnational legal process’. Simply put, the existing rules (both hard and soft) that govern behavior are evolving, and new rules are – or at the very least will be – emerging.
Third, contemporary regime building efforts driven largely by the United States seem poised to build a bifurcated legal regime separating out economic espionage (aimed at private sector interests) from other more traditional forms (aimed largely at states). The most recent evidence of this came during high-level talks between the United States and China, when it became clear that the agenda of the United States was to establish restrictive prohibitions on economically oriented acts of cyber espionage alongside a more permissive regime for traditional security related espionage. After the first day of talks, an American official said in relation to the theft of intellectual property, “we don’t do it, and we don’t think any country should do it.” For its part, China does not see a comparable distinction between economic and military security. As an example, the China Daily – a government oriented publication – wrote that “by dividing cyberespionage into ‘bad’ and ‘good’ activities, Washington is trying to dictate the rules for global cyberdomain, which is a public space.” Thus, it seems clear that the normative ground is shifting. But given the divergent views among two of the main actors, it remains unclear how fast and how far these normative changes will go to actually curbing unwanted state behavior in cyber space.
In order to make these arguments, this paper will proceed as follows. Part I will set out the precise content of the norm of non-interference under international law. Part II will examine state practice and opinio juris in relation to cyber espionage through the lens of the 2010 clandestine entry into Google’s servers – termed operation Aurora – arguing that there is no opinio juris to support state practice and that, even when caught, states tend to deny responsibility for acts of cyber espionage. Part III examines the emerging trend toward a more robust regime, which seeks to place greater constraints on the commission of acts of cyber

espionage. Finally, Part IV concludes with some recommendations regarding the potential course of evolution in this dynamic area of law.
## PART I - THE NORM OF NON-INTERFERENCE UNDER INTERNATIONAL LAW AND CYBER ESPIONAGE
At its most basic level, the principle of non-interference provides, that “[n]o state has the right to intervene in the internal or external affairs of another.” This general statement of principle seems to elude precise quantification and the jurisprudence is largely unhelpful in determining with any level of specificity the content of the prohibition on foreign interference. The clearest articulation of the norm from the International Court of Justice is that the principle forbids intervention that has a “bearing on matters in which each State is permitted, by the principle of State sovereignty, to decide freely.” The utility of this observation is limited by the fact that the modern regulatory state is free to decide almost anything within its territory, and because there is a serious gap between what a broad view of the norm of non-interference would require and what states actually do in their conduct toward one another. For that reason, determining the content of the norm with precision will require a case-by-case analysis to determine whether the specific conduct in question - in this case cyber espionage - falls within the scope of the prohibition.
There have been two broadly supported United Nations General Assembly Resolutions that have some bearing on the scope of the principle. The first is the 1965 the Declaration on the Inadmissibility of Intervention in the Domestic Affairs of States and the Protection of their Independence and Sovereignty (“Declaration on Intervention”). The second is the 1970 Declaration on Principles of International Law concerning Friendly Relations and Co-operation among States in Accordance with the Charter of the United Nations (“Friendly Relations Declaration”). These two documents are strikingly similar, with only modest differences. The relevant operative paragraph of the Friendly Relations Declaration is slightly more robust, stating:
No State or group of States has the right to intervene, directly or indirectly, for any reason whatever, in the internal or external affairs of any other State. Consequently, armed intervention and all other forms of interference or attempted threats against the personality of the State or against its political, economic and cultural elements, are in violation of international law.
Thus, within the Friendly Relations Declaration, which is widely regarded to reflect customary

law, there is an explicit prohibition on any form of interference with the political, economic and cultural elements of another state. However, the International Court of Justice narrowed this broad articulation in the Nicaragua decision, noting that:
A prohibited intervention must accordingly be one bearing on matters in which each State is permitted, by the principle of State sovereignty, to decide freely. One of these is the choice of a political, economic, social and cultural system, and the formulation of foreign policy. Intervention is wrongful when it uses methods of coercion in regard to such choices, which must remain free ones.
The problem is that the Court does not go on to define with any level of specificity what the content of the prohibition on interference actually is. The Court indicates that in order to be prohibited under international law an intervention must be one bearing on matters that each State is permitted, by the principle of State sovereignty, to decide freely. Unfortunately, rather than clarifying this position, the Court – curiously – goes on to consider whether there is any customary international law allowing intervention. Thus, the actual content of the norm of non-interference is left ill-defined and extremely vague.
The Nicaragua decision is further limited by the fact that it is decided at that outset that the "Court will define only those aspects of the principle which appear to be relevant to the resolution of the dispute." In this respect this case is lacking because, in many ways, the discussion of non-interference/non-intervention is subsumed within the larger discussion of the prohibition on the use of force that is the immediate subject matter of the decision. Therefore, the decision really provides only a partial discussion of the principle of non-interference. The Court explicitly chooses to discuss only those aspects of the principle relevant to the case before it. By definition then, the principle of non-interference goes beyond the narrow articulation presented by the Court. Consequently, states and legal scholars alike were left with only a partial explanation of the rule and with an unfinished legal test to determine which acts will actually offend the rule against foreign interference. What if any relevance does this limited test have for determining if a particular act of cyber espionage will offend the principle against non-interference? The simple answer is not much.
Pursuant to the test for interference posited in the Nicaragua case, in order to fall within the definition of prohibited intervention, the act in question must be intended to force or coerce a change of policy within the victim state. This formulation is not without support in the literature. Russell Buchan recently put forward a rote articulation of this test, in relation to cyber interference. Buchan argues:
All in all, in order to establish a violation of the non-intervention principle two questions must be addressed. First, is the intervention intended to force the victim State into a change of policy? [...] Secondly, if the intention to impose coercion is present, it must then be asked whether the application of coercion bears upon matters

U.S.), Judgment, 1986 I.C.J. 14, 202 (June 27) (“The principle of non-intervention involves the right of every sovereign State to conduct its affairs without outside interference; though examples of trespass against this principle are not infrequent, the Court considers that it is part and parcel of customary international law.”).
 Ibid., 205 (emphasis added).

which a state is entitled to freely determine itself.
The problem is that adopting this legal standard would exclude from international regulation all acts of cyber aggression that had no physical (or kinetic) effect, and which were motived by something other than a desire to influence policy within the target state. As an example, in February of 2011 the Internet security firm, McAfee, uncovered a major network infiltration using IP addresses located in China. The intrusion, labeled “Night Dragon”, targeted Western oil and energy companies and “[t]he goal of the intrusions was to obtain information on sensitive competitive proprietary operations and on financing of oil and gas field bids and operations.” In this case, valuable proprietary information was stolen and a significant benefit would have accrued to the relevant Chinese agencies or firms. However, because the objective was to obtain sensitive information and to use it against Chinese competitors, according to the circumspect test of the International Court of Justice in Nicaragua or the analysis put forward by Buchan, this would not qualify as an unlawful intervention or interference. This is because the breach was not intended to change a policy within the victim state.
This notion is deeply problematic given that the gravamen of the offence of unlawful interference is intervening in to the sphere over which the target state has authority. States – acting in their capacity as a sovereign – have the ability to regulate telecommunications, Internet service providers, intellectual property rights, and criminal sanctions related to data breaches. ## PART II – CYBER ESPIONAGE AND STATE PRACTICE
Evaluating state practice in relation to the collection of intelligence from human sources or through signals intercepts is difficult for obvious reasons, not least of which is the fact that these activities are meant to be clandestine. Evaluating the practice of states in relation to espionage committed via the Internet is more difficult still, because not only are the activities clandestine, but there are significant challenges with both technical and legal attribution, and even when breaches are uncovered, in many cases the victims are corporations – not states – and often times they do not report the breaches to their own government.
Therefore, employing case study methodology has distinct advantages over generalizations regarding state practice in this area. However, owing to the furtive character of espionage, selecting an appropriate case for study presents its own challenges. The surreptitious infiltration into the Google network discovered in 2010, termed Operation Aurora, was selected for study not only because of its high level of publicity, but also because it provoked a rare public response from the two major governments involved, the United States and China.
Certainly, there are disadvantages to employing case study methodology as well. More particularly, employing a single case study fails to account for the fact that many governments routinely engage in acts of economic espionage aimed squarely at private actors within competitor states. It is also requires generalization from one particular case, involving two state actors, to the wider groups of states. This has significant drawbacks because states do not behave in a uniform fashion, they are not motivated or constrained by the same things, and may take a differing view of a particular act. It is also impossible to ever truly know what is motivating a state to undertake a particular course of action. The fact is that generalizing from one observation is a poor mechanism for understanding the motivations of state behavior in a wider context. ## PART III - TRANSNATIONAL LEGALISM AND CYBER GOVERNANCE
As the above example shows, the international governance regime surrounding cyber espionage is still in its infancy. As such, simply determining whether these actions are legal or illegal is not enough. Rather, the legal rules and the norms that govern conduct in cyber space are in a period of flux and evolution. In order to understand these changes, one must understand the process of transnational legal evolution. The “[t]ransnational legal process describes the theory and practice of how public and private actors -- nation-states, international organizations, multinational enterprises, non-governmental organizations, and private individuals -- interact in a variety of public and private, domestic and international fora to make, interpret, enforce, and ultimately, internalize rules of transnational law.”63
In this way, the lens of transnational legalism provides several distinct advantages over the more traditional binary legal/illegal analysis noted above. It describes the complex and dynamic connection between the formation of norms within the international community and the reception and interpretation of those norms into domestic law and practice, while also providing an account of the influence of domestic norms on the development of international rules. It allows for a better and more complete understanding of the role of non-state actors, which are increasingly central players within the international community; moving away from the strictures of the traditional state centric analytical framework allows for a more holistic understanding of global affairs and has significantly greater descriptive validity – because it can accurately account for the fast moving and multi-faceted transnational interactions in the realm of cyber security generally and cyber espionage.
In transnational practice, “repeated interactions among states and a variety of domestic and transnational actors produce interpretations of applicable global norms which can be and are eventually internalized into states’ domestic values and processes.”64 Under transnational legal theory, “various agents of internalization – which include transnational norm entrepreneurs, governmental norm sponsors, transnational issue networks, issue linkages and interpretive communities – can provoke nations to move from grudging compliance to habitual internalized obedience with international rules.”65 Given the foregoing, the value of this theoretical model does not stop at its descriptive validity; rather, it has “both predictive capacity and explanatory

power regarding questions of causation."66 Transnational legal theory predicts that nations are most likely to comply with international norms if transnational legal processes are “aggressively triggered by other transnational actors in a way that forces interaction in forums capable of generating norms, followed by norm-internalization.”67 This process of “interaction and internalization in turn leads a national government to engage in new modes of interest-recognition and identity-formation in a way that eventually leads the nation-state back into compliance.”68
While it is appropriate to conclude that certain acts of cyber espionage are illegal as a matter of international law, and that there is no countervailing customary norm that provides a legal excuse or justification, it is equally appropriate to conclude that the raging practice of cyber espionage among states means that many have yet to subscribe to the norm and to internalize it in their conduct. Thus, with respect to cyber espionage, the global community is engaged at the earlier stages of the transnational legal process of repeated interaction and interpretation. This ongoing process is further complicated by the fact that there are competing norms being advanced by major actors with conflicting geostrategic interests.
Recent treaty negotiations aimed at Internet regulation broke down over divergent views over the role of the state in international Internet governance.69 The fault line between the United States and Europe, on the one hand, and a coalition of states led by Russia and China, on the other, has also been exposed in relation to the international norms applicable to information security. In September 2011, the Governments of China, the Russian Federation, Tajikistan and Uzbekistan sent a draft International Code of Conduct for information security to the United Nations addressed to the Secretary-General.
Under the terms of the Code of Conduct, each state voluntarily subscribing to the code pledges: “Not to use information and communications technologies, including networks, to carry out hostile activities or acts of aggression, pose threats to international peace and security”.70 At first blush, by sponsoring the Code of Conduct, it would appear that the Governments of China and Russia are prepared to voluntarily pledge not to use information and communications technologies to carry out hostile activities. Given that states now view network integrity as fundamental to their national security, covert network infiltration and economic cyber espionage is unquestionably a hostile act. Therefore, under the Code of Conduct, Russia and China are prepared to disavow the legitimacy of cyber espionage as a tool of strategic and economic policy. This, however, is completely disingenuous.

The fact is that both Russia and China are most persistent collectors of economic intelligence. According to a recent report from the Office of the National Counter Intelligence Executive, “Chinese actors are the world’s most active and persistent perpetrators of economic espionage. US private sector firms and cybersecurity specialists have reported an onslaught of computer network intrusions that have originated in China”.71 While at the same time “Russia’s intelligence services are conducting a range of activities to collect economic information and technology from US targets.”72
There are two main reasons that China and Russia engage in such aggressive economic cyber espionage, while at the same time they articulate a norm against it on the international stage. First, as a matter of geostrategic interest, “China and Russia view themselves as strategic competitors of the United States and are the most aggressive collectors of US economic information and technology.”73 Second, as a technical matter, these types of intrusions rarely get detected, and when they do they are notoriously difficult to attribute back to a state actor. As a consequence, Russia and China can act in a way that directly contradicts the norm that they are espousing, because there is a relatively low risk of discovery and attribution. It is not in their immediate interests to comply with that norm – the rewards are too high and the risks too low.
At the same time, countries like the United States and the United Kingdom are genuinely advocating for the establishment of, and reliance on, a comparable normative framework. Given the position of the United States as a global leader in intellectual property generation, it is not surprising that they would seek the enablement of a rules based regime that aims to hold the perpetrators of acts economic cyber espionage accountable for those actions. The most clear articulation of the policy of the United States Government toward acts of international economic cyber espionage is found in the May 2011 International Strategy for Cyber Space, signed by President Barack Obama. The International Strategy indicates:
The persistent theft of intellectual property, whether by criminals, foreign firms, or state actors working on their behalf, can erode competitiveness in the global economy, and businesses’ opportunities to innovate. The United States will take measures to identify and respond to such actions to help build an international environment that recognizes such acts as unlawful and impermissible, and hold such actors accountable.74
Given the foregoing it is not clear whether it is the position of the United States Government that the theft of intellectual property by state actors is currently recognized by the United States government as illegal, pursuant to international law, and that they are working to build on that within the international community. Or, if the United States Government will view this conduct as unlawful (pursuant to international law) once it has been accepted in the “international
Electronic copy available at: https://ssrn.com/abstract=2809828
environment”. But, it is clear that it is not in either the short or long-term interests of the United States Government, or any similarly situated government, to allow economic cyber espionage to continue, constrained only by the vague notions of illegality provided by customary law. Because the United States does not spy for its domestic companies,75 it has no ability to engage in tit-for-tat diplomacy; meaning in response to the infiltration of Google’s network, there is no incentive for the United States to undertake a comparable infiltration of Baidu - the dominant Chinese search engine. It is, however, perfectly rational against this factual backdrop, for the United States to seek to advance a normative construct of illegality to constrain the behavior of other state actors. Thus, pushing for a clearer set of norms acts as one tool to attempt to influence the unwanted behaviors of other states.76
In this way, traditional notions of customary law or the internationalization of general principles do not adequately describe the contemporary governance mechanisms in place that address cyber espionage. Rather, the governance landscape is comprised of emerging norms of conduct, supported by major international actors, that are pursuing their interests and seeking to constrain the ability of other states to exploit the intellectual property and confidential information of the companies that operate in their territory or are regulated by them. At the same time, many states engage in covert network infiltrations into the networks of companies located in their competitor states for economic, as well as political, reasons. When these activities are exposed, states are careful to distance themselves from the conduct. As noted, this suggests that there is no opinio juris supporting the conduct, that it offends the principle of non-interference, and that there is no competing legal rule changing that. But the story does not stop there.
At the international level, states like the United States are pushing to have an explicit norm recognized within the international community that prohibits economic cyber espionage, rather than subsisting on the implied norm against it that comes as part of the principle of non-interference. At the domestic level the majority of states already prohibit the types of network intrusions, data interference and intercepts that form the tools of the cyber espionage trade. But, more importantly, these states also – in some instances – seek to prohibit this conduct extraterritoriality and they do so with a legitimate basis under international law. All of this creates a unique legal position for economic cyber espionage: it is implicitly prohibited under customary international law, with a normative push to make it explicitly prohibited, all while states use municipal law to prohibit the conduct domestically and transnationally. Layered on top of this is the trend toward allowing a more permissive regime for national security and non-economic related acts of cyber espionage.

# PART IV – CONCLUSIONS
At this point in time, it is not entirely clear how the legal rules or norms of conduct will develop within this policy space. It is not surprising that the United States is pushing to create a strong normative and legal framework prohibiting acts of economic cyber espionage, because they have the most to lose and the least to gain from these types of activities. The United States generates major amounts of intellectual property and its firms routinely rely on sensitive and proprietary information in their business practices. At the same time, there is no ability within the United States’ system to translate stolen economic intelligence into an actionable intelligence product, because the United States does not have the ability to convey this stolen information to its domestic companies. After all, if the NSA were to steal the design for a revolutionary hybrid automotive engine from an Asian or European auto manufacturer, who would they give it to: Ford? General Motors? Chrysler? They would be effectively picking winners and losers in the free market economy, something which the United States Government tries not to do. It is also not surprising that the United States would seek a more permissive regime when it comes to security related intelligence, because the United States is widely believed to have the most sophisticated offensive cyber arsenal on the planet.
However, this push to bifurcate the rules – with one set of rules for economically motivated cyber espionage and one set for security related cyber espionage – sets up an interesting problem. The difficulty is that this framework would require target states to understand the motivation behind a particular intrusion in order to accurately gage the legality of that act. It also presupposes that a clear line can be drawn between economic and security interests – which of course is not true. Suppose for example that State A dropped a logic bomb on the central server of the national bank in State B. What if the purpose of this act was to activate the nefarious code only in the event of a kinetic conflict between the two states to undermine the economy within the target state? But, what if the purpose of the logic bomb was solely to undermine consumer confidence in that bank and to push consumer and business investments elsewhere? The act, placing nefarious code on the server, is the exact same. It is only the motivation that differs. And, in cyberspace, it will be difficult if not impossible to accurately assess the motivation behind any particular act. Therefore, the notion of setting up a dual regime with permissive rules for security related espionage and restrictive rules for economic espionage rests on top of two fallacies. First, that a target can tell the difference between acts that are economic in nature versus those that are security related, and that there is an actual difference between the two. And second, that a target will be able to ascertain why a particular clandestine cyber act was undertaken. This bifurcation of espionage related activities is simply not a sustainable way to create realistic rules of the road for espionage in cyber space.

# CYBER ESPIONAGE AND INTERNATIONAL LAW
## BY AARON SHULL
## INTRODUCTION
The place of espionage under international law is an uneasy one. Many look to state practice, and conclude that acts of espionage must surely be legal because so many states spy on one another. Others say that sending spies in to the territory of another state breaches the norm of territorial and sovereign integrity, and therefore acts of espionage should rightly be considered illegal pursuant to the relevant legal rules. The difficulty in assessing legality is amplified when analyzing cyber intrusions, because they do not offend the principle of territorial integrity in the same way that sending an actual state agent to gather human intelligence (colloquially referred to as “HUMINT”) would. This paper is an attempt to address these legal ambiguities.
However, because there is no public multilateral treaty that addresses acts of cyber espionage, recourse must be made to the customary rules to determine the position of espionage under international law. At its most basic level, customary law is comprised of the rules that emerge as a matter of past practice amongst nation states, and which come to govern future relations between them. The Statute of the International Court of Justice defines customary law as “evidence of a general practice accepted as law.” This has been interpreted to mean that for a customary norm of conduct to crystallize into a binding rule – gaining formal status under international law – two constituent criteria must be met. First, there must be widespread and consistent state practice. Second, the activity in question, or the abstinence of states from engaging in a particular activity, must be done out of a sense of legal compulsion. This second element, called *opinio juris*, is used to differentiate state actions that are legally obliged from those undertaken for some other purpose (like self-interest or comity).
The starting point for the application of international rules is the often cited *Lotus* principle, which asserts that a sovereign state may undertake any action they wish, as long as that action is not explicitly prohibited. The relevant question then becomes: Is there an explicit prohibition on acts of cyber espionage? The research goal of this paper is to answer that question, and in answering this question the paper will make three arguments.
First, that despite the fact that states routinely spy on each other, there is no evidence to support the proposition that state actors view cyber espionage as something that is legal under customary

And, if cyber intrusions offend the principle of non-interference, they are correctly considered to be illegal pursuant to the relevant customary rules.
Second, the forces that influence the behavior of both state and non-state actors in relation to cyber espionage are much more complicated than a simple determination of legality. Cyber espionage may be illegal, but this vague notion of illegality pursuant to an even vaguer general rule of customary law acts as an extremely poor constraint on state behaviour. Poorly constrained, it is no surprise that states have engaged in a massive campaign of political, economic and military cyber espionage activities. However, many states view the current situation characterized by widespread (and largely unchecked) acts of cyber espionage as unsustainable. It is the explosion in the number of targets created by the Internet that has led the global community in to a process of what international relations scholars call ‘regime’ building, or what international lawyers call the ‘transnational legal process’. Simply put, the existing rules (both hard and soft) that govern behavior are evolving, and new rules are – or at the very least will be – emerging.
Third, contemporary regime building efforts driven largely by the United States seem poised to build a bifurcated legal regime separating out economic espionage (aimed at private sector interests) from other more traditional forms (aimed largely at states). The most recent evidence of this came during high-level talks between the United States and China, when it became clear that the agenda of the United States was to establish restrictive prohibitions on economically oriented acts of cyber espionage alongside a more permissive regime for traditional security related espionage. After the first day of talks, an American official said in relation to the theft of intellectual property, “we don’t do it, and we don’t think any country should do it.” For its part, China does not see a comparable distinction between economic and military security. As an example, the China Daily – a government oriented publication – wrote that “by dividing cyberespionage into ‘bad’ and ‘good’ activities, Washington is trying to dictate the rules for global cyberdomain, which is a public space.” Thus, it seems clear that the normative ground is shifting. But given the divergent views among two of the main actors, it remains unclear how fast and how far these normative changes will go to actually curbing unwanted state behavior in cyber space.
In order to make these arguments, this paper will proceed as follows. Part I will set out the precise content of the norm of non-interference under international law. Part II will examine state practice and opinio juris in relation to cyber espionage through the lens of the 2010 clandestine entry into Google’s servers – termed operation Aurora – arguing that there is no opinio juris to support state practice and that, even when caught, states tend to deny responsibility for acts of cyber espionage. ## PART I - THE NORM OF NON-INTERFERENCE UNDER INTERNATIONAL LAW AND CYBER ESPIONAGE
At its most basic level, the principle of non-interference provides, that “[n]o state has the right to intervene in the internal or external affairs of another.” This general statement of principle seems to elude precise quantification and the jurisprudence is largely unhelpful in determining with any level of specificity the content of the prohibition on foreign interference. The clearest articulation of the norm from the International Court of Justice is that the principle forbids intervention that has a “bearing on matters in which each State is permitted, by the principle of State sovereignty, to decide freely.” The utility of this observation is limited by the fact that the modern regulatory state is free to decide almost anything within its territory, and because there is a serious gap between what a broad view of the norm of non-interference would require and what states actually do in their conduct toward one another. For that reason, determining the content of the norm with precision will require a case-by-case analysis to determine whether the specific conduct in question - in this case cyber espionage - falls within the scope of the prohibition.
There have been two broadly supported United Nations General Assembly Resolutions that have some bearing on the scope of the principle. The first is the 1965 the Declaration on the Inadmissibility of Intervention in the Domestic Affairs of States and the Protection of their Independence and Sovereignty (“Declaration on Intervention”). The second is the 1970 Declaration on Principles of International Law concerning Friendly Relations and Co-operation among States in Accordance with the Charter of the United Nations (“Friendly Relations Declaration”). These two documents are strikingly similar, with only modest differences. The relevant operative paragraph of the Friendly Relations Declaration is slightly more robust, stating:
No State or group of States has the right to intervene, directly or indirectly, for any reason whatever, in the internal or external affairs of any other State. Consequently, armed intervention and all other forms of interference or attempted threats against the personality of the State or against its political, economic and cultural elements, are in violation of international law.
Thus, within the Friendly Relations Declaration, which is widely regarded to reflect customary

law, there is an explicit prohibition on any form of interference with the political, economic and cultural elements of another state. However, the International Court of Justice narrowed this broad articulation in the Nicaragua decision, noting that:
A prohibited intervention must accordingly be one bearing on matters in which each State is permitted, by the principle of State sovereignty, to decide freely. One of these is the choice of a political, economic, social and cultural system, and the formulation of foreign policy. Intervention is wrongful when it uses methods of coercion in regard to such choices, which must remain free ones.
The problem is that the Court does not go on to define with any level of specificity what the content of the prohibition on interference actually is. The Court indicates that in order to be prohibited under international law an intervention must be one bearing on matters that each State is permitted, by the principle of State sovereignty, to decide freely. Unfortunately, rather than clarifying this position, the Court – curiously – goes on to consider whether there is any customary international law allowing intervention. Thus, the actual content of the norm of non-interference is left ill-defined and extremely vague.
The Nicaragua decision is further limited by the fact that it is decided at that outset that the "Court will define only those aspects of the principle which appear to be relevant to the resolution of the dispute." In this respect this case is lacking because, in many ways, the discussion of non-interference/non-intervention is subsumed within the larger discussion of the prohibition on the use of force that is the immediate subject matter of the decision. Therefore, the decision really provides only a partial discussion of the principle of non-interference. The Court explicitly chooses to discuss only those aspects of the principle relevant to the case before it. By definition then, the principle of non-interference goes beyond the narrow articulation presented by the Court. Consequently, states and legal scholars alike were left with only a partial explanation of the rule and with an unfinished legal test to determine which acts will actually offend the rule against foreign interference. What if any relevance does this limited test have for determining if a particular act of cyber espionage will offend the principle against non-interference? The simple answer is not much.
Pursuant to the test for interference posited in the Nicaragua case, in order to fall within the definition of prohibited intervention, the act in question must be intended to force or coerce a change of policy within the victim state. ## PART II – CYBER ESPIONAGE AND STATE PRACTICE
Evaluating state practice in relation to the collection of intelligence from human sources or through signals intercepts is difficult for obvious reasons, not least of which is the fact that these activities are meant to be clandestine. Evaluating the practice of states in relation to espionage committed via the Internet is more difficult still, because not only are the activities clandestine, but there are significant challenges with both technical and legal attribution, and even when breaches are uncovered, in many cases the victims are corporations – not states – and often times they do not report the breaches to their own government.
Therefore, employing case study methodology has distinct advantages over generalizations regarding state practice in this area. However, owing to the furtive character of espionage, selecting an appropriate case for study presents its own challenges. The surreptitious infiltration into the Google network discovered in 2010, termed Operation Aurora, was selected for study not only because of its high level of publicity, but also because it provoked a rare public response from the two major governments involved, the United States and China.
Certainly, there are disadvantages to employing case study methodology as well. More particularly, employing a single case study fails to account for the fact that many governments routinely engage in acts of economic espionage aimed squarely at private actors within competitor states. It is also requires generalization from one particular case, involving two state actors, to the wider groups of states. This has significant drawbacks because states do not behave in a uniform fashion, they are not motivated or constrained by the same things, and may take a differing view of a particular act. It is also impossible to ever truly know what is motivating a state to undertake a particular course of action. The fact is that generalizing from one observation is a poor mechanism for understanding the motivations of state behavior in a wider context. ## 1. The Aurora Exploit
On January 12, 2010, David Drummond, Senior Vice-President and Chief Legal Officer of Google publicly disclosed that his company had fallen victim to a major network infiltration. Drummond indicated on the company's official blog, that Google had “detected a highly sophisticated and targeted attack on our corporate infrastructure originating from China that resulted in the theft of intellectual property from Google.” During their internal investigations into the infiltration, the company determined that at least twenty other large companies in the Internet, finance, technology, media and chemical sectors were also targeted. They also uncovered evidence to suggest that “a primary goal of the attackers was accessing the Gmail accounts of Chinese human rights activists.”
According to subsequent investigations undertaken by the Internet security firm, McAfee, Operation Aurora initially targeted an individual user within Google. This individual would then receive a link in either an email or through an instant message that purported to be from a trusted source. Once the targeted user clicked on the link at their computer, they would be directed to a website hosted on servers in Taiwan that contained a malicious JavaScript payload. Once at the nefarious website, the Internet browser program being used to view the website automatically downloaded and executed the malicious program code, which included a zero-day Internet Explorer exploit. The exploit then executed the malicious payload, which set up a backdoor and the networked computer of the unsuspecting user was then remotely connected to command

## 3. The Response of the Government of the People's Republic of China
The Chinese Government responded forcefully to the accusations made by both Google and the United States Government. In almost perfect Orwellian double-speak, the spokesperson for the Foreign Ministry indicated, in response that: "It is China's consistent policy to promote the development of internet. China has its own national conditions and cultural traditions. It supervises internet according to law, which is in parallel with the international practice [sic]."^[60]^ She went on to say that "Hacking in whatever form and offence of others' privacy is prohibited by law in China. As a major victim of hacking in the world, China believes that the international community should intensify the cooperaion [sic] in jointly combating internet hacking so as to safeguard internet security and protect the privacy of citizens in accordance with law."^[61]^ So, the official position of the Government of China was that they were in no way responsible for the clandestine infiltration of Google's networks, and that the acts in question are considered criminal under Chinese domestic law.
When confronted, China fervently denied having any role in the infiltration of Google's network. What makes this denial such meaningful evidence is that the United States Government - and the public through wikileaks - knew that the Chinese Government coordinated the intrusions of Google's systems and that the operation was directed at the Politburo Standing Committee level.^[62]^ While the public protest of the United States Government was weak and somewhat confusing, it certainly would not count as acquiescence toward the practice. However, in the face of this protest the Chinese Government did not seek to justify its conduct using legal argument or by relying on an existing or emerging customary legal rule. Rather, the Chinese Government completely denied the allegations. In fact, in their public response the Chinese Government pushes for more intense international cooperation to combat these occurrences.
Put another way, there is no evidence of opinio juris surrounding the conduct of the states that engage in acts of economic cyber espionage or in the actions of the states that are victim. There has never been a public case of a state seeking to justify acts of cyber espionage as something that is defensible pursuant to international law. States do not feel compelled as a matter of legal obligation to engage in these acts, nor do states feel compelled to remain silent or acquiesce

## PART III - TRANSNATIONAL LEGALISM AND CYBER GOVERNANCE
As the above example shows, the international governance regime surrounding cyber espionage is still in its infancy. As such, simply determining whether these actions are legal or illegal is not enough. Rather, the legal rules and the norms that govern conduct in cyber space are in a period of flux and evolution. In order to understand these changes, one must understand the process of transnational legal evolution. The “[t]ransnational legal process describes the theory and practice of how public and private actors -- nation-states, international organizations, multinational enterprises, non-governmental organizations, and private individuals -- interact in a variety of public and private, domestic and international fora to make, interpret, enforce, and ultimately, internalize rules of transnational law.”63
In this way, the lens of transnational legalism provides several distinct advantages over the more traditional binary legal/illegal analysis noted above. It describes the complex and dynamic connection between the formation of norms within the international community and the reception and interpretation of those norms into domestic law and practice, while also providing an account of the influence of domestic norms on the development of international rules. It allows for a better and more complete understanding of the role of non-state actors, which are increasingly central players within the international community; moving away from the strictures of the traditional state centric analytical framework allows for a more holistic understanding of global affairs and has significantly greater descriptive validity – because it can accurately account for the fast moving and multi-faceted transnational interactions in the realm of cyber security generally and cyber espionage.
In transnational practice, “repeated interactions among states and a variety of domestic and transnational actors produce interpretations of applicable global norms which can be and are eventually internalized into states’ domestic values and processes.”64 Under transnational legal theory, “various agents of internalization – which include transnational norm entrepreneurs, governmental norm sponsors, transnational issue networks, issue linkages and interpretive communities – can provoke nations to move from grudging compliance to habitual internalized obedience with international rules.”65 Given the foregoing, the value of this theoretical model does not stop at its descriptive validity; rather, it has “both predictive capacity and explanatory

While it is appropriate to conclude that certain acts of cyber espionage are illegal as a matter of international law, and that there is no countervailing customary norm that provides a legal excuse or justification, it is equally appropriate to conclude that the raging practice of cyber espionage among states means that many have yet to subscribe to the norm and to internalize it in their conduct. Thus, with respect to cyber espionage, the global community is engaged at the earlier stages of the transnational legal process of repeated interaction and interpretation. This ongoing process is further complicated by the fact that there are competing norms being advanced by major actors with conflicting geostrategic interests.
Recent treaty negotiations aimed at Internet regulation broke down over divergent views over the role of the state in international Internet governance.69 The fault line between the United States and Europe, on the one hand, and a coalition of states led by Russia and China, on the other, has also been exposed in relation to the international norms applicable to information security. In September 2011, the Governments of China, the Russian Federation, Tajikistan and Uzbekistan sent a draft International Code of Conduct for information security to the United Nations addressed to the Secretary-General.
Under the terms of the Code of Conduct, each state voluntarily subscribing to the code pledges: “Not to use information and communications technologies, including networks, to carry out hostile activities or acts of aggression, pose threats to international peace and security”.70 At first blush, by sponsoring the Code of Conduct, it would appear that the Governments of China and Russia are prepared to voluntarily pledge not to use information and communications technologies to carry out hostile activities. Given that states now view network integrity as fundamental to their national security, covert network infiltration and economic cyber espionage is unquestionably a hostile act. Therefore, under the Code of Conduct, Russia and China are prepared to disavow the legitimacy of cyber espionage as a tool of strategic and economic policy. This, however, is completely disingenuous.

The fact is that both Russia and China are most persistent collectors of economic intelligence. According to a recent report from the Office of the National Counter Intelligence Executive, “Chinese actors are the world’s most active and persistent perpetrators of economic espionage. US private sector firms and cybersecurity specialists have reported an onslaught of computer network intrusions that have originated in China”.71 While at the same time “Russia’s intelligence services are conducting a range of activities to collect economic information and technology from US targets.”72
There are two main reasons that China and Russia engage in such aggressive economic cyber espionage, while at the same time they articulate a norm against it on the international stage. First, as a matter of geostrategic interest, “China and Russia view themselves as strategic competitors of the United States and are the most aggressive collectors of US economic information and technology.”73 Second, as a technical matter, these types of intrusions rarely get detected, and when they do they are notoriously difficult to attribute back to a state actor. As a consequence, Russia and China can act in a way that directly contradicts the norm that they are espousing, because there is a relatively low risk of discovery and attribution. It is not in their immediate interests to comply with that norm – the rewards are too high and the risks too low.
At the same time, countries like the United States and the United Kingdom are genuinely advocating for the establishment of, and reliance on, a comparable normative framework. Given the position of the United States as a global leader in intellectual property generation, it is not surprising that they would seek the enablement of a rules based regime that aims to hold the perpetrators of acts economic cyber espionage accountable for those actions. The most clear articulation of the policy of the United States Government toward acts of international economic cyber espionage is found in the May 2011 International Strategy for Cyber Space, signed by President Barack Obama. The International Strategy indicates:
The persistent theft of intellectual property, whether by criminals, foreign firms, or state actors working on their behalf, can erode competitiveness in the global economy, and businesses’ opportunities to innovate. The United States will take measures to identify and respond to such actions to help build an international environment that recognizes such acts as unlawful and impermissible, and hold such actors accountable.74

But, it is clear that it is not in either the short or long-term interests of the United States Government, or any similarly situated government, to allow economic cyber espionage to continue, constrained only by the vague notions of illegality provided by customary law. Because the United States does not spy for its domestic companies,75 it has no ability to engage in tit-for-tat diplomacy; meaning in response to the infiltration of Google’s network, there is no incentive for the United States to undertake a comparable infiltration of Baidu - the dominant Chinese search engine. It is, however, perfectly rational against this factual backdrop, for the United States to seek to advance a normative construct of illegality to constrain the behavior of other state actors. Thus, pushing for a clearer set of norms acts as one tool to attempt to influence the unwanted behaviors of other states.76
In this way, traditional notions of customary law or the internationalization of general principles do not adequately describe the contemporary governance mechanisms in place that address cyber espionage. Rather, the governance landscape is comprised of emerging norms of conduct, supported by major international actors, that are pursuing their interests and seeking to constrain the ability of other states to exploit the intellectual property and confidential information of the companies that operate in their territory or are regulated by them. At the same time, many states engage in covert network infiltrations into the networks of companies located in their competitor states for economic, as well as political, reasons. When these activities are exposed, states are careful to distance themselves from the conduct. As noted, this suggests that there is no opinio juris supporting the conduct, that it offends the principle of non-interference, and that there is no competing legal rule changing that. But the story does not stop there.
At the international level, states like the United States are pushing to have an explicit norm recognized within the international community that prohibits economic cyber espionage, rather than subsisting on the implied norm against it that comes as part of the principle of non-interference. At the domestic level the majority of states already prohibit the types of network intrusions, data interference and intercepts that form the tools of the cyber espionage trade. But, more importantly, these states also – in some instances – seek to prohibit this conduct extraterritoriality and they do so with a legitimate basis under international law. All of this creates a unique legal position for economic cyber espionage: it is implicitly prohibited under customary international law, with a normative push to make it explicitly prohibited, all while states use municipal law to prohibit the conduct domestically and transnationally. Layered on top of this is the trend toward allowing a more permissive regime for national security and non-economic related acts of cyber espionage.

# PART IV – CONCLUSIONS
At this point in time, it is not entirely clear how the legal rules or norms of conduct will develop within this policy space. It is not surprising that the United States is pushing to create a strong normative and legal framework prohibiting acts of economic cyber espionage, because they have the most to lose and the least to gain from these types of activities. The United States generates major amounts of intellectual property and its firms routinely rely on sensitive and proprietary information in their business practices. At the same time, there is no ability within the United States’ system to translate stolen economic intelligence into an actionable intelligence product, because the United States does not have the ability to convey this stolen information to its domestic companies. After all, if the NSA were to steal the design for a revolutionary hybrid automotive engine from an Asian or European auto manufacturer, who would they give it to: Ford? General Motors? Chrysler? They would be effectively picking winners and losers in the free market economy, something which the United States Government tries not to do. It is also not surprising that the United States would seek a more permissive regime when it comes to security related intelligence, because the United States is widely believed to have the most sophisticated offensive cyber arsenal on the planet.
However, this push to bifurcate the rules – with one set of rules for economically motivated cyber espionage and one set for security related cyber espionage – sets up an interesting problem. The difficulty is that this framework would require target states to understand the motivation behind a particular intrusion in order to accurately gage the legality of that act. It also presupposes that a clear line can be drawn between economic and security interests – which of course is not true. Suppose for example that State A dropped a logic bomb on the central server of the national bank in State B. What if the purpose of this act was to activate the nefarious code only in the event of a kinetic conflict between the two states to undermine the economy within the target state? But, what if the purpose of the logic bomb was solely to undermine consumer confidence in that bank and to push consumer and business investments elsewhere? The act, placing nefarious code on the server, is the exact same. It is only the motivation that differs. And, in cyberspace, it will be difficult if not impossible to accurately assess the motivation behind any particular act. Therefore, the notion of setting up a dual regime with permissive rules for security related espionage and restrictive rules for economic espionage rests on top of two fallacies. First, that a target can tell the difference between acts that are economic in nature versus those that are security related, and that there is an actual difference between the two. And second, that a target will be able to ascertain why a particular clandestine cyber act was undertaken. This bifurcation of espionage related activities is simply not a sustainable way to create realistic rules of the road for espionage in cyber space.

# CYBER ESPIONAGE AND INTERNATIONAL LAW
## BY AARON SHULL
## INTRODUCTION
The place of espionage under international law is an uneasy one. Many look to state practice, and conclude that acts of espionage must surely be legal because so many states spy on one another. Others say that sending spies in to the territory of another state breaches the norm of territorial and sovereign integrity, and therefore acts of espionage should rightly be considered illegal pursuant to the relevant legal rules. The difficulty in assessing legality is amplified when analyzing cyber intrusions, because they do not offend the principle of territorial integrity in the same way that sending an actual state agent to gather human intelligence (colloquially referred to as “HUMINT”) would. This paper is an attempt to address these legal ambiguities.
However, because there is no public multilateral treaty that addresses acts of cyber espionage, recourse must be made to the customary rules to determine the position of espionage under international law. At its most basic level, customary law is comprised of the rules that emerge as a matter of past practice amongst nation states, and which come to govern future relations between them. The Statute of the International Court of Justice defines customary law as “evidence of a general practice accepted as law.” This has been interpreted to mean that for a customary norm of conduct to crystallize into a binding rule – gaining formal status under international law – two constituent criteria must be met. First, there must be widespread and consistent state practice. Second, the activity in question, or the abstinence of states from engaging in a particular activity, must be done out of a sense of legal compulsion. This second element, called *opinio juris*, is used to differentiate state actions that are legally obliged from those undertaken for some other purpose (like self-interest or comity).
The starting point for the application of international rules is the often cited *Lotus* principle, which asserts that a sovereign state may undertake any action they wish, as long as that action is not explicitly prohibited. The relevant question then becomes: Is there an explicit prohibition on acts of cyber espionage? The research goal of this paper is to answer that question, and in answering this question the paper will make three arguments.
First, that despite the fact that states routinely spy on each other, there is no evidence to support the proposition that state actors view cyber espionage as something that is legal under customary

Smith, Symposium, *State Intelligence Gathering and International Law: Keynote Address*, 28 MICH. J. INT'L L. 543, 545 (2007); Roger D. Scott, *Territorially Intrusive Intelligence Collection and International Law*, 46 A.F.L. REV. 217 (1999); Christopher D. Baker, *Tolerance of International Espionage: A Functional Approach*, 19 AM. U. INT'L L. REV. 1091, 1092 (2004).

international law. In this regard, while instances of cyber espionage may not offend the territorial integrity of the target state like human spying would, a sound legal conclusion can be drawn that certain intrusions will offend the principle of non-interference under international law. And, if cyber intrusions offend the principle of non-interference, they are correctly considered to be illegal pursuant to the relevant customary rules.
Second, the forces that influence the behavior of both state and non-state actors in relation to cyber espionage are much more complicated than a simple determination of legality. Cyber espionage may be illegal, but this vague notion of illegality pursuant to an even vaguer general rule of customary law acts as an extremely poor constraint on state behaviour. Poorly constrained, it is no surprise that states have engaged in a massive campaign of political, economic and military cyber espionage activities. However, many states view the current situation characterized by widespread (and largely unchecked) acts of cyber espionage as unsustainable. It is the explosion in the number of targets created by the Internet that has led the global community in to a process of what international relations scholars call ‘regime’ building, or what international lawyers call the ‘transnational legal process’. Simply put, the existing rules (both hard and soft) that govern behavior are evolving, and new rules are – or at the very least will be – emerging.
Third, contemporary regime building efforts driven largely by the United States seem poised to build a bifurcated legal regime separating out economic espionage (aimed at private sector interests) from other more traditional forms (aimed largely at states). The most recent evidence of this came during high-level talks between the United States and China, when it became clear that the agenda of the United States was to establish restrictive prohibitions on economically oriented acts of cyber espionage alongside a more permissive regime for traditional security related espionage. After the first day of talks, an American official said in relation to the theft of intellectual property, “we don’t do it, and we don’t think any country should do it.” For its part, China does not see a comparable distinction between economic and military security. As an example, the China Daily – a government oriented publication – wrote that “by dividing cyberespionage into ‘bad’ and ‘good’ activities, Washington is trying to dictate the rules for global cyberdomain, which is a public space.” Thus, it seems clear that the normative ground is shifting. But given the divergent views among two of the main actors, it remains unclear how fast and how far these normative changes will go to actually curbing unwanted state behavior in cyber space.
In order to make these arguments, this paper will proceed as follows. Part I will set out the precise content of the norm of non-interference under international law. Part II will examine state practice and opinio juris in relation to cyber espionage through the lens of the 2010 clandestine entry into Google’s servers – termed operation Aurora – arguing that there is no opinio juris to support state practice and that, even when caught, states tend to deny responsibility for acts of cyber espionage. Part III examines the emerging trend toward a more robust regime, which seeks to place greater constraints on the commission of acts of cyber

## PART I - THE NORM OF NON-INTERFERENCE UNDER INTERNATIONAL LAW AND CYBER ESPIONAGE
At its most basic level, the principle of non-interference provides, that “[n]o state has the right to intervene in the internal or external affairs of another.” This general statement of principle seems to elude precise quantification and the jurisprudence is largely unhelpful in determining with any level of specificity the content of the prohibition on foreign interference. The clearest articulation of the norm from the International Court of Justice is that the principle forbids intervention that has a “bearing on matters in which each State is permitted, by the principle of State sovereignty, to decide freely.” The utility of this observation is limited by the fact that the modern regulatory state is free to decide almost anything within its territory, and because there is a serious gap between what a broad view of the norm of non-interference would require and what states actually do in their conduct toward one another. For that reason, determining the content of the norm with precision will require a case-by-case analysis to determine whether the specific conduct in question - in this case cyber espionage - falls within the scope of the prohibition.
There have been two broadly supported United Nations General Assembly Resolutions that have some bearing on the scope of the principle. The first is the 1965 the Declaration on the Inadmissibility of Intervention in the Domestic Affairs of States and the Protection of their Independence and Sovereignty (“Declaration on Intervention”). The second is the 1970 Declaration on Principles of International Law concerning Friendly Relations and Co-operation among States in Accordance with the Charter of the United Nations (“Friendly Relations Declaration”). These two documents are strikingly similar, with only modest differences. The relevant operative paragraph of the Friendly Relations Declaration is slightly more robust, stating:
No State or group of States has the right to intervene, directly or indirectly, for any reason whatever, in the internal or external affairs of any other State. Consequently, armed intervention and all other forms of interference or attempted threats against the personality of the State or against its political, economic and cultural elements, are in violation of international law.
Thus, within the Friendly Relations Declaration, which is widely regarded to reflect customary

law, there is an explicit prohibition on any form of interference with the political, economic and cultural elements of another state. However, the International Court of Justice narrowed this broad articulation in the Nicaragua decision, noting that:
A prohibited intervention must accordingly be one bearing on matters in which each State is permitted, by the principle of State sovereignty, to decide freely. One of these is the choice of a political, economic, social and cultural system, and the formulation of foreign policy. Intervention is wrongful when it uses methods of coercion in regard to such choices, which must remain free ones.
The problem is that the Court does not go on to define with any level of specificity what the content of the prohibition on interference actually is. The Court indicates that in order to be prohibited under international law an intervention must be one bearing on matters that each State is permitted, by the principle of State sovereignty, to decide freely. Unfortunately, rather than clarifying this position, the Court – curiously – goes on to consider whether there is any customary international law allowing intervention. Thus, the actual content of the norm of non-interference is left ill-defined and extremely vague.
The Nicaragua decision is further limited by the fact that it is decided at that outset that the "Court will define only those aspects of the principle which appear to be relevant to the resolution of the dispute." In this respect this case is lacking because, in many ways, the discussion of non-interference/non-intervention is subsumed within the larger discussion of the prohibition on the use of force that is the immediate subject matter of the decision. Therefore, the decision really provides only a partial discussion of the principle of non-interference. The Court explicitly chooses to discuss only those aspects of the principle relevant to the case before it. By definition then, the principle of non-interference goes beyond the narrow articulation presented by the Court. ## PART II – CYBER ESPIONAGE AND STATE PRACTICE
Evaluating state practice in relation to the collection of intelligence from human sources or through signals intercepts is difficult for obvious reasons, not least of which is the fact that these activities are meant to be clandestine. Evaluating the practice of states in relation to espionage committed via the Internet is more difficult still, because not only are the activities clandestine, but there are significant challenges with both technical and legal attribution, and even when breaches are uncovered, in many cases the victims are corporations – not states – and often times they do not report the breaches to their own government.
Therefore, employing case study methodology has distinct advantages over generalizations regarding state practice in this area. However, owing to the furtive character of espionage, selecting an appropriate case for study presents its own challenges. The surreptitious infiltration into the Google network discovered in 2010, termed Operation Aurora, was selected for study not only because of its high level of publicity, but also because it provoked a rare public response from the two major governments involved, the United States and China.
Certainly, there are disadvantages to employing case study methodology as well. More particularly, employing a single case study fails to account for the fact that many governments routinely engage in acts of economic espionage aimed squarely at private actors within competitor states. It is also requires generalization from one particular case, involving two state actors, to the wider groups of states. This has significant drawbacks because states do not behave in a uniform fashion, they are not motivated or constrained by the same things, and may take a differing view of a particular act. It is also impossible to ever truly know what is motivating a state to undertake a particular course of action. The fact is that generalizing from one observation is a poor mechanism for understanding the motivations of state behavior in a wider context.
